skill.name: doc-consistency-reviewer
skill.description: Documentation Consistency Reviewer checks that documentation matches actual code implementation. It finds discrepancies between README/docs and source code, configuration, or API contracts. Use when user wants to verify documentation accuracy, check for outdated docs, or validate API documentation. Triggers: doc review, documentation consistency, verify docs, check outdated docs.
skill.summary: Verifies documentation matches code implementation. Finds outdated or inconsistent descriptions in README and docs folders.
skill.author: hylarucoder

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The 64 external_commands detections are markdown code blocks with shell examples in documentation, not executable code. The 17 weak_crypto detections are base64-encoded content in JSON/YAML files. The 9 obfuscation detections are high-entropy structured data patterns, not obfuscated payloads. Network detection is legitimate metadata (GitHub source URL). No actual security risks found.

content.value_statement: Documentation often becomes outdated as code evolves. This skill systematically compares documentation against source code, configuration files, and API contracts to identify inconsistencies before they cause problems for users.
actual_capabilities: Compares README and docs against actual source code implementation
Validates API documentation against OpenAPI/proto/GraphQL schemas
Checks configuration and environment variable documentation
Detects security configuration inconsistencies between docs and code
Generates structured inconsistency reports with severity levels
Validates that code examples in documentation are accurate
limitations: Cannot verify external documentation on third-party sites
Does not execute code to validate behavior
Cannot determine intent behind undocumented features

use_cases.title: Pre-Release Documentation Review
use_cases.description: Before shipping a release, run this skill to audit all documentation for consistency with code. Catch outdated API references, deprecated feature mentions, and configuration errors before users encounter them.

use_cases.title: Onboarding Documentation Check
use_cases.description: When joining a new project, use this skill to quickly identify outdated documentation. Get a comprehensive list of discrepancies that could confuse new developers or lead them astray.

use_cases.title: Security Documentation Audit
use_cases.description: Focus on security-related documentation. Verify that security configurations, authentication methods, and permission models described in docs actually match the code implementation.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Documentation Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the doc-consistency-reviewer skill to review the README and docs folder in this project. Compare each documented claim against the actual source code and configuration files. List all inconsistencies you find with evidence from both the docs and code.
prompt_templates.scenario: General review of all documentation against code

prompt_templates.title: API Documentation Validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Focus on API documentation. Check that all API endpoints, request/response formats, and error codes documented match the actual implementation in the source code and any OpenAPI/proto/GraphQL schema files.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to validate API documentation accuracy

prompt_templates.title: Security Configuration Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the doc-consistency-reviewer skill with focus on security. Verify that all security configurations, authentication flows, permission models, and encryption settings documented are actually implemented in the code. Flag any security-related inconsistencies as P0/P1 issues.

prompt_templates.title: Configuration and Environment Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Review all configuration documentation including environment variables, config files, and feature flags. Verify that documented defaults, required settings, and available options match what the code actually expects and uses.

best_practices: Run documentation reviews before every release to catch regressions
Focus security reviews on authentication, authorization, and data protection documentation
Use the severity levels (P0-P3) to prioritize which inconsistencies to fix first
Update documentation and code together to maintain consistency
anti_patterns: Documenting features that do not exist in the codebase
Leaving code examples in documentation that no longer work
Documenting configuration defaults that differ from actual code defaults
Updating documentation without verifying against the actual implementation

faq.question: What files does this skill review?
faq.answer: The skill reviews README.md and all files in docs/ folder by default. It compares these against source code, configuration files, and API contract files like OpenAPI specs, proto files, GraphQL schemas, and TypeScript type definitions.

faq.question: How does it determine what is correct?
faq.answer: The skill follows the principle 'code is truth'. When documentation conflicts with code, the source code implementation is treated as the source of truth. API contracts (OpenAPI/proto/GraphQL) are treated as the single source of truth for interface definitions.

faq.question: Does it modify the documentation?
faq.answer: No, this skill only reviews and reports inconsistencies. It generates a detailed report of issues found but does not make any changes to documentation or code files.

faq.question: What severity levels are used?
faq.answer: P0: Security issues or severe misleading content. P1: Core functionality inconsistencies that will cause failures. P2: Minor inconsistencies that may cause confusion. P3: Small issues like formatting or typos.

faq.question: Can I focus on specific areas?
faq.answer: Yes, you can specify focus areas in your prompt such as 'focus on API documentation' or 'review only security configuration'. The skill will prioritize those areas in its review.

faq.question: What types of inconsistencies does it detect?
faq.answer: The skill detects missing documentation, outdated information, incorrect examples, mismatched configuration, wrong API signatures, security setting discrepancies, and terminology inconsistencies.
